DataElement.preferredName: Central Laboratory Gleason Score for Prostate Cancer Ki67 Measurement Outcome Receive Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A response used to determine whether or not the Gleason Score and the Ki67 measurement results from a laboratory delivering the data for a particular study had been received.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Central Laboratory Gleason Score for Prostate Cancer Ki67 Measurement Outcome Receive
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A laboratory delivering the data for a particular study._The score derived from universally embraced prostate cancer grading system developed by Dr. Donald F. Gleason in 1977. The system provides a reproducible description of the glandular architecture of prostate tissue to which a pathologist assigns a score depending primarily on the microscopic patterns of cancerous glands and cell morphology. The system correlates well with behavior at the extremes: Gleason 1+1 tumors are the most well differentiated, slowly growing and rarely spread; Gleason 4+5 tumors are the most poorly differentiated, often widely metastatic at the time of diagnosis. In the commoner intermediate grade tumors, however, behavior is extremely variable._The determination of the amount of Ki-67 protein present in a sample._The result of an action._To take, accept, or get something offered.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A laboratory delivering the data for a particular study.

Property.preferredDefinition: The score derived from universally embraced prostate cancer grading system developed by Dr. Donald F. Gleason in 1977. The system provides a reproducible description of the glandular architecture of prostate tissue to which a pathologist assigns a score depending primarily on the microscopic patterns of cancerous glands and cell morphology. The system correlates well with behavior at the extremes: Gleason 1+1 tumors are the most well differentiated, slowly growing and rarely spread; Gleason 4+5 tumors are the most poorly differentiated, often widely metastatic at the time of diagnosis. In the commoner intermediate grade tumors, however, behavior is extremely variable.:The determination of the amount of Ki-67 protein present in a sample.:The result of an action.:To take, accept, or get something offered.

Concepts.definition: The score derived from universally embraced prostate cancer grading system developed by Dr. Donald F. Gleason in 1977. The system provides a reproducible description of the glandular architecture of prostate tissue to which a pathologist assigns a score depending primarily on the microscopic patterns of cancerous glands and cell morphology. The system correlates well with behavior at the extremes: Gleason 1+1 tumors are the most well differentiated, slowly growing and rarely spread; Gleason 4+5 tumors are the most poorly differentiated, often widely metastatic at the time of diagnosis. In the commoner intermediate grade tumors, however, behavior is extremely variable.
The determination of the amount of Ki-67 protein present in a sample.
To take, accept, or get something offered.
